bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Adrian Macia, January 20, 1941

div1.p: Hench informs Macia that he is anxious to make the final arrangements to memorialize Camp Lazear. He hopes that Macia and his partners will join him in this endeavour.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Adrian Macia, January 20, 1941
div1.opener:
Y F.
January 20, 1941
My dear Senor Macia:
div1.p:
You may have wondered why you have not heard from me since
the Washington and Jefferson ceremony the last of October. I have been
very busy and as a matter of fact have been hoping to hear from you, as
I believe you said I might hear from you when your partner returned to
Cuba. I am very anxious indeed to make the final arrangements to memorialize
the little shack on the former site of Camp Lazear, and I am most anxious
to hear from you, in the hope that your partners will have agreed to join
you in what I believe to be a most worthy cause.

I am rather worried lest the little building may have been
further demolished, as part of it was demolished between the time I saw
it in April and the time Mr. Moran determined its identity in October.
I shall be most grateful for any information you will give me.

It is possible that I can come down in March and conclude
matters, discussing the entire affair with you, but meanwhile I am anxious
to know whether you plan to be in Cuba during the latter two weeks of
March.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. Senor Adrian Macia
Manzana de Gomez 325
Havana, Cuba
Wrote again 3/4/41 -longhand.
